relationships.notes: Acts introduces Agrippa I as stretching out his hand against the church belonging to Jesus, treating violence against the apostles as a way to oppose the risen Lord’s movement and curry favor with Jerusalem audiences.
After executing James, Agrippa arrests Peter during the Festival of Unleavened Bread, holds him under heavy guard, and plans a public trial before God’s intervention frees the apostle.

traits.persecution_of_church: Portrayed as a ruler who lays violent hands on members of the Jerusalem church, killing James the son of Zebedee with the sword and arresting Peter to please certain Judeans.
traits.political_motives: Acts highlights his desire to curry favor with the people by attacking key leaders of the Jesus movement.
traits.public_display_and_death: While dressed in royal robes and receiving acclamation as a god in Caesarea, is struck down by an angel of the Lord because he does not give glory to God and is eaten by worms and dies.
traits.theological_interpretation: His death is framed as divine judgment, contrasting human self-exaltation with God’s sovereignty and the continued growth of the word.
